solution_line_template: A red ticket is equal to {blue_per_red} blue tickets, and a yellow is equal to ten red tickets, so a yellow ticket is also equal to {red_per_yellow} * {blue_per_red} = <<{red_per_yellow}*{blue_per_red}={blue_per_yellow}>>{blue_per_yellow} blue tickets.
It takes {yellow_needed} yellow tickets to win a Bible, or {yellow_needed} * {blue_per_yellow} = <<{yellow_needed}*{blue_per_yellow}={blue_needed}>>{blue_needed} blue tickets.
Tom has {tom_yellow} yellow tickets, which are worth {tom_yellow} * {blue_per_yellow} = <<{tom_yellow}*{blue_per_yellow}={blue_from_yellow}>>{blue_from_yellow} blue tickets.
He also has {tom_red} red tickets, which are worth {tom_red} * {blue_per_red} = <<{tom_red}*{blue_per_red}={blue_from_red}>>{blue_from_red} blue tickets.

Added with his {tom_blue} blue tickets, he has {blue_from_yellow} + {blue_from_red} + {tom_blue} = <<{blue_from_yellow}+{blue_from_red}+{tom_blue}={tom_total_blue}>>{tom_total_blue} blue tickets' worth of tickets.
So he still needs to earn {blue_needed} - {tom_total_blue} = <<{blue_needed}-{tom_total_blue}={blue_needed_more}>>{blue_needed_more} blue tickets.
